hierarchy.entry_domain: Access Control for Assets and Information

active_learning.discussion_prompt: How would you apply this concept in your work environment?
active_learning.peer_teaching: In pairs, explain authentication vs. authorization using PACS diagrams (e.g., credential reader -> controller -> door unlock flow). Switch roles for teach-back, then share one key takeaway with the group, linking to prior knowledge of logical access control.
active_learning.problem_solving: Design a PACS for a fictional corporate HQ: Identify risks (e.g., tailgating, insider threats), select components/technologies, map NIST controls (PE-3, AC-2), and outline deployment steps per NIST SP 800-116. Role-play a security audit of a 'breached' facility and use think-pair-share to correct misconceptions (e.g., 'Physical access isn't a cyber threat').

distractor_protocol.step: Identify common misconceptions about the topic
Ensure distractors are similar in length and complexity
Include partial truths that require deeper understanding

flashcard_generation.system_prompt: You are an expert flashcard generator for cybersecurity education, specializing in Physical Access Control Systems (PACS) within the topic hierarchy: Cybersecurity > Asset Security > Information and Asset Handling > Access Control for Assets and Information > Physical Access to Assets > Physical Access Control Systems. Generate 25-35 high-quality flashcards using the exact schema provided. Cover all learning objectives (spanning Bloom's: Remember/Understand, Apply/Analyze, Evaluate/Create), scaffolding layers (Foundation to Integration), and draw from research context (definitions: PACS, auth/authz, credential, PIV; standards: NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5 (PE-3 Physical Access Control, AC-2 Account Management), NIST SP 800-116 (smart cards/PIV), HSPD-12, NIST RMF). Include big picture: PACS role in preventing physical bypass of digital controls for compliance/mastery. Incorporate prior knowledge (links to logical access control), misconceptions (auth=authz, PACS only tech, physical not cyber), and active learning examples (e.g., RFID vs biometrics debate, PACS design exercise). Use flashcard schema precisely: Balance types/layers/objectives. Distractors from protocol. Explanations detailed with references. Output ONLY a JSON array of flashcards, e.g., [{'type': '...', ...}]. No extra text.
